Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as dde9bc12ed98a89a0ce662be580738efadf2578c

I think the previous behavior is correct. If you have property name of "Type", "Capacity", or "Protocol"..., then it is expected to be valid value.

It seems like that we needed to update how the property are populated in your system instead of the code here.

> I think the previous behavior is correct. If you have property name of "Type", "Capacity", or "Protocol"..., then it is expected to be valid value.
> 
> It seems like that we needed to update how the property are populated in your system instead of the code here.

Sure, So we have different ideas, Could we discuss this on discord?

sure, but I guess the main question is

- what is populated in those property if it is not valid.

> sure, but I guess the main question is
> 
> - what is populated in those property if it is not valid.

Yeah, I see, I will update this patch again, thanks 😊

> > sure, but I guess the main question is
> > 
> > - what is populated in those property if it is not valid.
> 
> Yeah, I see, I will update this patch again, thanks 😊

Updated
An internal error on its own is not a failure in bmcweb.  You've changed the code to basically ignore the interface failures, which is not how we generally handle this.

> An internal error on its own is not a failure in bmcweb.  You've changed the code to basically ignore the interface failures, which is not how we generally handle this.

It has been updated according to the discussion on discord

> THis code was correct before.

It has been updated according to the discussion on discord

> THis code was correct before.

It has been updated according to the discussion on discord
Trying to get this one off the queue, so I fixed the comments.  @george can you please retest this solves your problem?
empty seems like an internal error, unknown seems like something we should leave off. I.e. just check for Unknown
empty seems like an internal error, unknown seems like something we should leave off. I.e. just check for Unknown

Same here, I don't see Unknown in the list, this is going to fail the validator if Unknown

http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Protocol.json#/definitions/Protocol

            "enum": [
                "PCIe",
                "AHCI",

                "AHCI": "Advanced Host Controller Interface (AHCI).",
                "CXL": "Compute Express Link.",
                "DVI": "DVI.",
                "DisplayPort": "DisplayPort.",
                "Ethernet": "Ethernet.",
                "FC": "Fibre Channel.",
                "FCP": "Fibre Channel Protocol for SCSI.",
                "FCoE": "Fibre Channel over Ethernet (FCoE).",
                "FICON": "FIbre CONnection (FICON).",
                "FTP": "File Transfer Protocol (FTP).",
                "GenZ": "GenZ.",
                "HDMI": "HDMI.",
                "HTTP": "Hypertext Transport Protocol (HTTP).",
                "HTTPS": "Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS).",
                "I2C": "Inter-Integrated Circuit Bus.",
                "InfiniBand": "InfiniBand.",
                "MultiProtocol": "Multiple Protocols.",
                "NFSv3": "Network File System (NFS) version 3.",
                "NFSv4": "Network File System (NFS) version 4.",
                "NVLink": "NVLink.",
                "NVMe": "Non-Volatile Memory Express (NVMe).",
                "NVMeOverFabrics": "NVMe over Fabrics.",
                "OEM": "OEM-specific.",
                "PCIe": "PCI Express.",
                "RoCE": "RDMA over Converged Ethernet Protocol.",
                "RoCEv2": "RDMA over Converged Ethernet Protocol Version 2.",
                "SAS": "Serial Attached SCSI.",
                "SATA": "Serial AT Attachment.",
                "SFTP": "SSH File Transfer Protocol (SFTP).",
                "SMB": "Server Message Block (SMB).  Also known as the Common Internet File System (CIFS).",

                "TFTP": "Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP).",
                "UDP": "User Datagram Protocol (UDP).",
                "UHCI": "Universal Host Controller Interface (UHCI).",
                "USB": "Universal Serial Bus (USB).",
                "VGA": "VGA.",
                "iSCSI": "Internet SCSI.",
                "iWARP": "Internet Wide Area RDMA Protocol (iWARP)."
            },
seems like Unkonwn is covered as `std::nullopt` now.
same here. Unknown is covered as `std::nullopt`
Is this supposed to be a warning? It doesn't make sense to log an error and return success.
Is this supposed to be a warning?

I am good with this but this is different than how we fixed this on https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/63041

Is this the pattern we should follow? 
 std::nullopt means leave property off (e.g. Unknown)
Invalid means throw an internal error ?
sure, I can change that. Ed added a comment in that commit but gave a +2

I have a minor preference for this one, because "invalid" means that the input was invalid, nullopt means there's no output.

Invalid is different than not present.  But my preference here isn't strong;  The only thing that's important is that we follow DBUS_USAGE.md as far as the user is concerned.

> I have a minor preference for this one, because "invalid" means that the input was invalid, nullopt means there's no output.

Ack. Looks go with this direction from now on.
Should this really return or just continue? You are going to leave off additional properties on a warning..?
Should this really return or just continue?
